content.description: Start up on edges as the wall steepens into a smoother section. Weave back and forth a bit looking for the bigger crimps and edges. Wonder if you really should be getting that close to the other route(s).
content.location: Second line from the left. This is the left-most line on the more-or-less level base of the cliff, just before a slight downhill trend at the base.

content.description:
A gritty, dirty, somewhat loose choss-fest up a slick, wet gully. What's not to like?

Actually, it's not that bad, and later in the year the gully probably isn't even wet. It'll still be dirty, though. Few people will climb this.

Start up the left side of the gully for two bolts, then step across to the right side for the third and subsequent bolts.

After the fourth bolt some lower-angled choss appears briefly, followed by a roof and some steeper bits. You might have to look around a bit for holds you feel might stay on the wall.
content.protection: 9 bolts, chain anchors. You might want to use slings at bolts 3, 4, and/or 5.
content.location: Starts up the left side of the gully on the right side of the crag (2 bolts, then across the gully).

content.description:
A bouldery, at times tenuous start leads to the right-side-ledge with a big, dirty pocket at eye level. Find your way off the ledge and use what holds you can (some of them are a bit small).

A good pump awaits just before the final steep part.

A fairly straightforward start to the ubiquitous right-side-of-the wall ledge (you'll pass 3 very closely spaced bolts just before the ledge).

From the ledge large positive holds quickly give way to a blank-appearing area, which is then followed by an enjoyable roof. Another ledge, one more bolt, and then the anchors.

Beware of loose stuff near the top, and be careful of the flake on your right as you pass the last bolt to the chains.
content.protection: 13 (!) bolts, anchors. One or two of the bolts may be profitably skipped.

content.description:
Start up on thin crimps for a couple of bolts. Larger edges await, followed by a hands-free ledge. At the ledge, contemplate the fairly-blank-appearing dihedral above.

After being intimidated for a while, and after not seeing an obvious path, commit and start up and through the shallow dihedral. After the dihedral surmount a bulge. The angle then eases a bit to the chains (there is a bolt from the converging route to the right that one could clip, but it's a bit to the right).
content.protection: 9 bolts (or 10 bolts if you want), chain anchors.
content.location: The sixth line from the left. This line is easily identifiable as the bolts immediately right of the line that goes through the weakness in the roof after traversing a bit below the angled part of the roof.

content.description: Start up a over a bit of broken rock onto a ledge, then a few tricky, thin moves into crimps. Reach a blank area, figure out which way to go, and hit the anchors.
content.location: The left-most bolted line. The start is slightly downhill from the the base of most of the wall,  past a tree on left.

content.description:
A thin, somewhat burly start to a brief respite on slightly less steep rock for a few bolts. A steeper, thinner section awaits as you climb up under the roof and trend right towards the narrowest spot of the overhang. A couple of pockets along the way help out, then a committing couple of moves on less-than-satisfactory feet get you established under the roof.

A burly-but-well-protected move over the roof will have you heaving a sigh of relief (and cursing the local shrubbery).

After the roof, pass a set of anchors on your right while continuing up easier ground. Somewhat spacier bolts lead to a bit-of-a-nerve-wracking top out on a ledge. Be wary of lots of small, loose debris on the top-out ledge.
content.location:
Approximately mid point on the wall, this line leads up to the roof which dominates the left side of the wall, then follows the roof line as it trends right and up to a narrow spot in the roof.

Note that the anchors are set back on a ledge and aren't visible from the ground.

content.description:
Head up below a small roof, with a slightly-committing move to clip the bolt above the roof if you're of average height.

Arrive at a perplexing blank section, and decide on which side you'll tackle it. One side is somewhat harder and more committing than the other.
content.location: Third line from the left. Climbs over a small roof to a very blank-looking section.

content.description:
A tricky start with loose, blocky feet leads to some dirty, lichen-dusted holds you wish were just a little more positive.

A rest at the wide ledge is followed by some stemming trickery up a short, shallow dihedral to a spot just before the final steep section.

Small, technical holds with perplexing feet lead over the top.
content.location: Ninth from the left. There are two (presumably) abortive lines to this line's right, each with a pulled first bolt, and one more line that starts just left of the wide, dirty-looking chimney.

content.description: A committing couple of moves off the ground using a huge pocket, then easier ground to a small roof followed by a slight bulge before the anchors.
content.location: Fourth line from the left. Heads up over a small roof, then to the left of a bulging section.

content.description: Four well-spaced bolts of easy climbing lead to a roof (crux) requiring powerful pulls on small holds if one is to surmount. Weird technical face climbing on broken crimps left of the bolts are next. Now up and back right to another roof where another series of powerful and (by now) pumping edges guard a difficult clip. Try to sneak out a good shake out above, as the climbing is sustained and a bit cryptic till the chains. A good endurance route at the grade- feels long for AF standards. The bolting style/placements date this route (along with the SMC hangers. (late 1980's?)
content.protection: 9 Bolts all the way (a bit spaced). Anchors at top.
content.location: The best approach for this route is to beat up the scree slope to the Shame Wall (behind, but to the right of the outhouse), and when you reach the Shame wall, trend down hill (left) 50 feet or so to a small ledge area above a steep vegetated slope. Belay here- there are 3 routes and All Men Are Mortal is the middle line. Watch the potential ground fall getting to the second bolt.
